title: Widow to become nurse after seeing 'amazing' hospital staff care for late husband
text:

A young widow is training to become a specialist nurse after her husband died from heart transplant complications.

Louise Hughes, 26, was left heartbroken in May 2018 when Dave, 32, died 11 weeks after getting a new heart.

Employed as a nursery worker at the time, Louise was inspired to start a new career by the “amazing” nurses who cared for him.

The mum started a college course just four months after Dave’s death and began a nursing degree last month.

(Image: SWNS)

(Image: SWNS)

When she qualifies Louise wants to specialise as a transplant nurse and work at Wythenshawe Hospital, in south Manchester, where her husband was treated.

Louise lives in Wigan with her and Dave’s son George, now three.

The University of Salford undergraduate said: “It was amaz­ing to see the way the nurses cared for him and also dealt with us.

“I decided that I could make a difference and help people in the same way I was helped.

“I feel like I’m in a perfect position to do the job well.”

Dave, a trainee mechanic, had a congenital heart defect meaning his main arteries were the wrong way round.

In 2013, one year after he met Louise, Dave’s condition deteriorated to the point doctors told him he would eventually need a heart transplant to survive.

(Image: SWNS)

(Image: Lee McLean / SWNS)

In February 2018, as Dave’s health was beginning to decline, the family received the life-changing call they had been waiting for and travelled to the Newcastle Freeman Hospital to undergo the gruelling 12 hour surgery.

He was unconscious for two and a half weeks after the op, and Louise arranged for their wedding to take place in hospital on March 23, once he woke.

The ceremony, with only nine close family members and friends including baby George, was arranged by hospital staff.

(Image: Lee McLean / SWNS)

(Image: Lee McLean / SWNS)

Just six weeks after their marriage, while Dave was still at Newcastle Freeman, his health took a drastic downturn as it emerged his donated heart was failing.

Louise and her family now host a memorial fundraising event on February 22 every year, which was the day in 2018 Dave got his heart transplant.

Since then Louise has helped raise £21,000 for the Freeman Heart and Lung Transplant Association.

The Mirror campaigned for Max and Keira’s Law – which means that from next spring everyone will be a donor unless they opt out.
description: Louise Hughes is retraining to take up a career as a specialist transplant nurse after her husband, Dave, tragically died after heart transplant failure at the age of 32
